title: 106_s2748
content: The Act may be cited as the "Russian-American Trust and Cooperation Act of 2000". The Congress finds that the Russian Federation operates an intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba, leased for $100-300 million annually. The facility covers a 28 square-mile area with over 1,500 Russian personnel. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, covers a 28 square-mile area with over 1,500 personnel. The base has tracking dishes and a satellite system used for intercepting communications. It has been reported to gather sensitive information about US military operations and collect personal information about US citizens. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, is reportedly used for espionage against the United States, collecting personal information and engaging in cyberwarfare. The facility's operational significance grew significantly after a directive from Russian President Boris Yeltsin in 1996. The Russian government has invested over $3 billion in modernizing the facility, as confirmed by former US officials. Former US officials confirm Russian expansion and upgrade of the Lourdes facility in Cuba, with a high-ranking Russian military delegation visiting in 1999 to discuss operations. PROHIBITION ON BILATERAL DEBT RESCHEDULING AND FORGIVENESS FOR THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION. Prohibition on rescheduling or forgiving Russian Federation's bilateral debt to the US until Russia closes intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba. President can waive this if deemed necessary for national interest. The President can waive the prohibition on rescheduling or forgiving Russian Federation's debt to the US if deemed necessary for national interest. Detailed facts supporting the waiver must be included in a written certification to Congress every 180 days. The certification may be submitted in classified form if deemed appropriate. The President must submit a report every 180 days to Congress detailing the extent to which certain requirements are being met. SEC. 4. REPORT ON THE CLOSING OF THE INTELLIGENCE FACILITY AT LOURDES, CUBA. The President must submit a report every 120 days detailing the actions taken by Russia to close the intelligence facility in Lourdes, Cuba, and the efforts of US departments to verify these actions.
